did.unittitle: David Alan Richards Collection of Rudyard Kipling

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into thirteen groupings: May 2004 Acquisitions, February 2005 Acquisition, October 2008 Acquisition, November 2008 Acquisition, October 2009 Acquisition, November 2010 Acquisition, September 2011 Acquisition, November 2013 Acquisition, August 2014 Acquisition, November 2014 Acquisition, October 2015 Acquisition, December 2016 Acquisition, and July 2017 Acquisition.

bioghist.head: Rudyard Kipling (1865-1936)
bioghist.p: Rudyard Kipling (1865-1936), the English author, was born in Bombay, India, on 30 December 1865, to John Lockwood Kipling, professor in the Sir Jamsetjee Jeejeebhoy School of Art in Bombay, India, and his wife, Alice (Macdonald) Kipling. Kipling was sent to England at the age of five, where he boarded and schooled until he took a job at a newspaper, the Civil and Military Gazette , in Lahore, Pakistan, in 1882. He started publishing stories in the 1880s while working at the Gazette and later at the Pioneer . He returned to England briefly in 1889 and then travelled and settled in the United States for several years. He continued to write prolifically during the 1890s, and by the time he returned to England in late 1896, he was already very well-known. In 1902 Kipling settled at "Bateman's" in Burwash, East Sussex, where he resided until his death on 18 January 1936.
Additional biographical information can be found in standard print and online sources.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The David Alan Richards Collection of Rudyard Kipling is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The David Alan Richards Collection of Rudyard Kipling consists of material by and relating to English author Rudyard Kipling. There are autograph and typescript letters, signed, from Kipling to others as well as some third-party letters relating to Kipling or the collection. Correspondents include Edward Bok, Ladies Home Journal , Sir Philip Burne-Jones, Moncure D. Conway, C. S. Jarvis, John Lockwood Kipling, A. E. W. Mason, H. Cotton Minchin, S. S. McClure Company, E. W. Stoddard, and others. Writings include a corrected typescript draft of Kipling's first novel, The Light that Failed (1890), an autograph manuscript draft and illustrations for The Princess in the Pickle-bottle , and autograph manuscript and typescript drafts of a number of poems. In addition, there are illustrated works by Kipling's father, John Lockwood Kipling, and a bibliography of Kipling's work. Other papers include scrapbooks, consisting chiefly of clippings, photographs, postcards and other printed ephemera, artwork, and memorabilia relating to Kipling.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing in 2015, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, identified by month and year of acquisition.

Descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during processing.
Former call numbers: Uncat Ms Vault File, Uncat MSS 743, Uncat MSS 1047, Uncat MSS 1236, Uncat MSS 1255, and Uncat MSS 1292.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2004 Acquisitions consists of letters from Rudyard Kipling to others.
Former call number: Uncat Ms Vault Kipling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2005 Acquisition consists of a corrected draft of Kipling's first novel, The Light that Failed , bound together with an autograph letter, signed, from Kipling to an unidentified editor at Lippincott's Magazine .

did.unittitle: The Light that Failed , draft, typescript and typescript carbon, corrected, with proofreaders' marks
Autograph letter, signed, from Kipling to [Anthony Hope Hawkins]
"Bibliography of Works by Rudyard Kipling" by Lloyd Chandler, autograph manuscript and typescript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Former call number: Uncat Ms Vault File.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter, signed, from Kipling to "Lady Sackville"
Typed letter, signed, from E. M. Blaikie to H. F. H. Caldwell
The Princess in the Pickle-bottle , illustrations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The November 2010 Acquisition features Mary C. Ensor's papers relating the Kipling family. Mary C. Ensor's father was the Kipling family doctor and Mary received drawing lessons from John Lockwood Kipling. The Ensor papers include correspondence, an autograph book, and numerous original drawings by John Lockwood Kipling. There are approximately eighteen autograph letters, signed, from different members of the Kipling family to Mary and Dr. Ensor.

did.unittitle: Autograph letters, signed, from Kipling to others
Mary C. Ensor Collection of Kipling

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2011 Acquisition includes correspondence, drafts of writings, and photographs. There are autograph and typescript letters, signed, from Kipling to Edward Bok, editor of the Ladies Home Journal , Shane Chichester, and others, as well as a third-party letter from A. E. W. Mason to Doubleday and Company. Writings include a corrected autograph manuscript draft by Kipling of "The Last Rhyme of True Thomas," circa 1894, and "The Rhyme of Johnny Grundy and His Grey Mare" by John Lockwood Kipling. The latter work, dated "Bombay, January 1869," is illustrated.
There are photographs of Kipling, Kipling's wife Caroline, his parents, and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subdivisions for Writings and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The November 2013 Acquisition contains drafts and other material relating to writings, a notebook, photographs, memorabilia, and commemorative material relating to Rudyard Kipling.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Include's "The Mother of the Man" by Hall Caine, typescript

did.unittitle: The Light that Failed , "Censorship Dialogue Script" for film adaptation, typescript mimeograph
"The Literary Beggar" by Sparham Sheldrake, poem, autograph manuscript, signed
The Princess in the Pickle-bottle , illustrations
Pen and ink portrait of Kipling by Stanley D. Lovegrove, signed and framed

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The August 2014 Acquisition contains writings, correspondence, artwork, clippings and printed ephemera, photographs, scrapbooks, and other papers by or relating to Rudyard Kipling. Correspondence includes letters from Kipling to E. W. Stoddard, the publishers S. S. McClure Company, Charles Oman, and others, as well as third-party letters from A. E. W. Mason to Doubleday and Company, from his father John Lockwood Kipling to Monsure D. Conway, and from Sir Philip Burne Jones to Lucy Clifford.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by material type and title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2014 Addition contains the following material: two autograph letters, signed, from Kipling to others; two autograph manuscript drafts; a printing plate for "The King's Ankus," several photographs of Kipling and family, including his parents and daughters, Josephine and Elsie; and his wife's fan, signed by numerous people during the early 1890s.

did.unittitle: Autograph letter, signed, from Kipling to Fred M. Hopkins
Autograph letter, signed, from Kipling to "Lizzie"
"Puck [of?] Pook's Hill," poem, autograph manuscript, signed

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One autograph letter, signed, dated April 11, 1895, from Rudyard Kipling to "Dear Clarke," and one autograph letter, signed, from John Lockwood Kipling to "Dear Margot."
